messages.text:
*ARA Project – Architecture & Setup Confirmation*
• Firestore is the database, not the server. It is used purely for data storage and querying.
• Render hosts the backend services. Backend APIs (Node/Express) will run on Render.
 => Access to Render is required for service setup, environment variables, and deployments.
• React is hosted separately as a static application. Deployed via Firebase Hosting or an equivalent static hosting provider.
• GitHub repositories will live under DevPixel SEG :white_check_mark: Repos will be created and maintained there with standard branching and access controls.
• OpenAI access is required. OpenAI APIs will be consumed only via the backend, with keys securely stored in Render environment variables.
• Project environments will be maintained separately:
    ◦ Dev – Active development and testing
    ◦ UAT – Pre-production validation and UAT ?!
    ◦ Prod – Live production environment
• Branding and domain details are the remaining inputs needed to proceed quickly.
This includes:
Final brand name
Logo, color palette, fonts
Domain name and DNS ownership

messages.text:
ARA Project – Architecture & Setup (POC)
• Firestore: Database only (not a server)
• Backend: Node/Express hosted on Render *(access required)*
• Frontend: React app hosted as a static site (Firebase Hosting or equivalent)
• GitHub: Repos under DevPixel SEG :white_check_mark:
• OpenAI: Accessed only via backend; keys stored in Render env vars *(access required)*
• Environment: Single POC environment only 
• Branding & Domain: Out of scope for POC
*Next steps today*
• Clone the DevPixel website codebase and clean up unnecessary logic
• Once Render and OpenAI access is received, configurations will be updated.

messages.text:
*<@U37KPJ30D>* *<@UM3V8V1NK>*
I’ve implemented the neighbor-based rehydration logic for matched chunks.
 For each matched chunk we now include its immediate neighbors: *(order-1, order, order+1)*.
This works well when matches are localized or in a continuous range.
 Example: if the matched chunks are *(7, 8, 9, 10, 11)*, the final hydrated set becomes *(6–12)*, which stays within the model’s context window and produces correct answers.
However, when the vector search returns *many matches spread across the document* (e.g., orders like *2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 27*), the neighbor expansion produces multiple disjoint ranges (e.g., *1–12 and 26–28*).
 This causes the hydrated context to grow very large (1.5M+ characters) and exceed the LLM context limit.

<@U37KPJ30D> <@UM3V8V1NK>
*HTML vs DOCX performance comparison*
I added a new document in Firebase and stored its chunks using *.html* files. I then tested two queries where the *parent section size is ~120k+ characters* in both cases (HTML and normal docs).
I ran and recorded both scenarios and attached the screenshots below.
*Test cases:*
• *HTML docs:*
 _“The main parts or phases in the Software Engineering process are?”_
 → This picks chunks from the HTML-based document.
• *Normal docs (DOCX):*
 _“If a former spouse is still named as beneficiary under a retirement plan but a divorce decree states that the spouse waived all rights to plan benefits, who is entitled to receive the death benefit—and why?”_
 → This picks chunks from the non-HTML document.
Even though both parent sections are ~120k+ characters, the response times are noticeably different between HTML and non-HTML sources.

So far, our neighboring logic has been defined assuming smaller chunk documents, where “before” and “after” simply meant retrieving the previous and next chunk documents. In the current case, the section itself is very large (e.g., Chapter 6, Section III, Part D ~104 pages), and the neighboring logic would therefore operate within this large section, not across multiple small chunk documents.

That means rehydration would need to locate the matched content within this section and pull a larger context window before and after that match from the same document. If this is the intended approach, could you advise on how we should define those boundaries safely?

<@UM3V8V1NK>  <@U37KPJ30D> <@U06EHNXKZ1D>
I’ve updated the logic so that we now *consider all chunks with a score > 0.5* (not just Top-5).
For the question *“When do I need to distribute the 402(f) notice?”*, here’s what’s happening now:
After score filtering, we get matches from *multiple sections* (Chapter 6 – Sections 4 and 7).
As per our current strategy, we first try to load the *full parent section*, but both sections are very large and exceed the context size limit.
We then fall back to the *neighbor-chunk strategy*, where we identified *11 neighboring chunks*.
• However, due to the *context size cap*, we hit the limit at *chunk 3*, so the final context does *not include all relevant neighbor chunks* 
• Because of this, the LLM ends up responding that the information is not available, even though it exists in another nearby section.

<@U08SA26H4LT> <@U08FS8VDFSR> Consolidation of what was discussed with Abhi.
*ARA / Document chunking + retrieval*
1. Pick one additional chapter (preferably with a question bank) to use for validation testing.
2. Use the existing script to break that chapter down further by structure (at least one or two more levels where headings are clear).
3. Run a blind A/B test:
• Version A = current chunking 3 levels
• Version B = more granular structured chunks
     Compare answer quality + whether context is missing.
4. Implement / enforce rehydration guardrails
5. Stop optimizing formatting for now; prioritize chunk size + context control first (footnotes can be handled after baseline works if req).
6. Maintain a clean “what’s in the DB” folder/list with exact file naming and version discipline (don’t re-upload randomly; track what’s live).

*<@U37KPJ30D>* May I share the following observation in the *<#C0A2H47EDK9|>* channel?
I enabled a VPN and connected via the Netherlands, then recorded the screen. I’m seeing the text load after ~5–6 seconds in that case. <@U37KPJ30D>
Earlier, the landing page text was being fetched directly from Firebase on the frontend without a backend endpoint. I’ve updated the logic to fetch this content via a new backend endpoint (`getText`). With this change, even when enabling a Germany VPN, the text now loads within ~1 second—similar to India—so the response time is consistent across regions. I’ve also deployed the latest code changes to both the frontend and backend.

messages.text: How is it going folks?

<@UM3V8V1NK> <@U37KPJ30D>
Please review this approach and share your feedback.
 Let me know if this flow looks correct or if you have any suggestions or improvements.
```User Question
      ↓
Basic Check
• Is it empty?
• Is it too short?
• Is it readable?
      ↓
LLM Understanding Check
• LLM reads the question
• Tries to understand user intent
      ↓
+----------------------------------------+
| Is the question clear and complete?   |
+----------------+-----------------------+
                 |
        +--------+--------+
        |                 |
      CLEAR            UNCLEAR
        |                 |
        v                 v
Use As-Is        Deep Understanding Step
                • Understand intent
                • Detect missing info
                • Identify unclear words
                        ↓
                Vector Hint Search (Helper Step)
                • Search unclear query in Vector DB
                • Get related topics / hints / keywords
                        ↓
                Context Detection (LLM + Hints)
                • Identify missing topic
                • Identify missing time
                • Identify missing entity
                        ↓
                Smart Rewrite by LLM
                • Use vector hints + reasoning
                • Add missing context
                • Add time / subject
                • Rewrite into clean question
                        ↓
                Rewrite Quality Check
                • Is rewritten query clear?
                • Is meaning preserved?
                        ↓
                Final Clean Question
                        ↓
           Search in Vector Database
                        ↓
         Find Best Matching Document Chunks
                        ↓
       Send Chunks + Question to LLM
                        ↓
                   Final Answer```

messages.text:
<@U37KPJ30D> <@UM3V8V1NK>
*Query Construction – Phase 1: Unclear Concept Detection (Estimated: 6–8 hours)*
*Scope:*
 Implement the first stage of Query Construction (QC), focused on detecting unclear concepts from the user query before retrieval.
*What we are building:*
• LLM-based clarity detection → classify query as *CLEAR / UNCLEAR*
• Extract *only unclear words/phrases directly from user query*
• Return *strict JSON output*:
 `{ isClear: true/false, concepts: [...] }`
• Backend *logging + debugging visibility*
• Test with *real production queries*

```LLM Prompt — Unclear Concept Detection (QC Phase-1)
Analyze the following user inquiry.

If the inquiry is clear and self-contained, respond ONLY with valid JSON:

{
  "isClear": true,
  "concepts": []
}

If the inquiry is unclear, ambiguous, or missing important context, respond ONLY with valid JSON:

{
  "isClear": false,
  "concepts": ["list", "of", "unclear", "words or phrases taken directly from the inquiry"]
}

Rules:
- Extract ONLY unclear words or phrases that already appear in the inquiry.
- Do NOT introduce new words.
- Do NOT explain.
- Do NOT add commentary.
- Return strict JSON only.

User Inquiry:
"<USER_QUERY>"```

messages.text:
<@UM3V8V1NK> <@U37KPJ30D>
Currently I have changed the QC flow to *derive unclear concepts using ARA vector-store context instead of generic LLM reasoning*.
*What I did:*
Took the *original user query*
Retrieved *matching chunks from vector DB*
Built *combined context from those chunks*
Passed this context into the *detectUnclearConcepts LLM prompt*
• Now the unclear detection is *grounded on ARA source material*
*Prompt being used:*
```You are a regulatory query analysis engine for the American Retirement Association (ARA).

Your task:
Analyze the user's inquiry using ONLY the provided ARA source material.

Identify any unclear or ambiguous concepts.

Unclear concepts include:
- Ambiguous regulatory terms
- Missing plan or distribution context
- Overloaded legal terminology
- Implicit legal assumptions

DO NOT rewrite the question.
DO NOT answer the question.
DO NOT introduce new terms.

Return STRICT JSON only.

If the inquiry is fully clear:
{
  "isClear": true,
  "concepts": []
}

If unclear:
{
  "isClear": false,
  "concepts": [
    {
      "concept": "<short phrase from or implied by the inquiry>",
      "reason": "<why unclear using ARA material>",
      "category": "ambiguous | missing | overloaded | implicit",
      "confidence": <number between 0 and 1>
    }
  ]
}```
Example Output (real run):
```[QC] QC context built: 32930 chars
{
  isClear: false,
  concepts: [
    {
      concept: "402f notice",
      reason: "The ARA material discusses notice and consent timing but does not define what a 402f notice is or its timing requirements.",
      category: "missing",
      confidence: 0.86
    },
    {
      concept: "distribute the 402f notice",
      reason: "Timing depends on distribution form and commencement date, which are not specified.",
      category: "missing",
      confidence: 0.78
    },
    {
      concept: "before 2007",
      reason: "Unclear whether this refers to distribution year, notice date, or plan year, which affects how the pre-2007 timing rule is applied.",
      category: "ambiguous",
      confidence: 0.74
    }
  ]
}```
Can I share this with Aris for validation and next steps?

You are a regulatory query analysis engine for the American Retirement Association (ARA).

Your task:
Analyze the user's inquiry using ONLY the provided ARA source material.

Identify any unclear or ambiguous concepts.

Unclear concepts include:
- Ambiguous regulatory terms
- Missing plan or distribution context
- Overloaded legal terminology
- Implicit legal assumptions

DO NOT rewrite the question.
DO NOT answer the question.
DO NOT introduce new terms.

Return STRICT JSON only.

If the inquiry is fully clear:
{
  "isClear": true,
  "concepts": []
}

If unclear:
{
  "isClear": false,
  "concepts": [
    {
      "concept": "<short phrase from or implied by the inquiry>",
      "reason": "<why unclear using ARA material>",
      "category": "ambiguous | missing | overloaded | implicit",
      "confidence": <number between 0 and 1>

<@UM3V8V1NK> <@U37KPJ30D>
 I implemented *QC – Step 2 as an experimental flow* to validate how a *new reconstructed query* would look and how it improves answer quality.
*What I did (technical flow):*
1. Ran *vector search using only the extracted unclear concepts* → to fetch _clarification-only regulatory chunks_.
2. Combined:
• Original user query
• Unclear concepts
• Clarification chunks
 → and passed them to the LLM with a *query reconstruction prompt* to generate *one precise legal research query*.
3. Used this *rewritten query* for final vector retrieval + answer generation.
Reconstruction Prompt Used
```You are a regulatory query reconstruction engine for the American Retirement Association (ARA).

Rewrite the inquiry into a legally precise, retrieval-optimized research query — it should be ONE query.

Rules:
- DO NOT answer the question.
- DO NOT introduce facts not present.
- DO NOT change the user's intent.
- DO clarify ambiguous legal concepts.
- DO inject missing regulatory context.
- DO optimize the query for regulatory document retrieval.

Original Inquiry:
${originalQuery}

Unclear Concepts:
${concepts.map(c => `- ${c}`).join("\n")}

Regulatory Reference Material:
${context}

Return ONLY the rewritten query string.```
:small_blue_diamond: Example
*Original Query:*
 When do I need to distribute the 402f notice before 2007?
*Rewritten Query Generated:*
 For distributions made in pre-2007 years under IRC §402(f) and the related Treasury regulations governing the timing of the “402(f) special tax notice” (including the notice-and-consent timing rules measured from the “annuity starting date”/distribution commencement date for lump sums and installment payments, the reasonable administrative delay exception, and the pre-2007 90-day (rather than 180-day) maximum period between furnishing the notice and completing the distribution), what is the required earliest/latest deadline by which the plan administrator must furnish the §402(f) notice to the participant (and spouse, if applicable) before making the distribution?

*Outcome:*
*The rewritten query produced a more accurate, legally precise, and regulation-aligned answer*.
• This step is *experimental / research-only*, used to validate the QC approach — *not final production logic yet*.

*<@UM3V8V1NK>*
I’ve made an update to the backend *chunk delete function*.
*Earlier behavior:*
 Deleting a chunk only removed that chunk, which could leave gaps in the `order` sequence.
*What’s changed now:*
 After deleting a chunk, the system automatically *re-adjusts the order numbers* of the remaining chunks.
 For example, if chunk *19* is deleted:
• Chunk 20 → becomes 19
• Chunk 21 → becomes 20
• … and so on till the last chunk
This ensures there are *no gaps between chunk orders*, so our neighboring / sequential logic based on `order` remains unaffected.
I verified this logic in *dev* and then pushed the changes to *prod*.
*Production output after deleting a duplicate chunk (order = 59):*

<@U37KPJ30D> <@UM3V8V1NK>
 <@U06EHNXKZ1D> and I have outlined the backend implementation plan for the Firestore structure change.
Firestore Structure Change (New Approach)
We are moving to a new structure where the *entire chapter hierarchy is stored inside a single Chapter document*, using a *JSON string* field (`Parts`).
*Structure:*
```
Chapters/
└── {chapterId}
    ├── id: "Chapter 6"
    └── Parts: "{
          "Section III": {
              "id": "Section III",
              "Parts": {
                  "Part D": {
                      "id": "Part D",
                      "Parts": {
                          "5": {
                              "id": "5",
                              "file": "https://...docx",
                              "textRef": "Texts/{textId}"
                          }
                      }
                  }
              }
          }
      }"```
*Text Storage (Separate Collection)*
In the `Parts` JSON string, we will *NOT store the extracted text content* of the file.
 Instead, we will store the actual extracted text in a separate collection:
`Texts/{textId}`

And in the JSON string, we will store only the reference (`textRef`) for the specific Section/Part/Subpart
Backend Endpoints to Implement / Rewrite
• `createChapter`
• `updateChapter`
• `addChunk`
 (internally uses: `addSection()`, `addPart()`, `addSubpart()`, `parseFileName()`)
• `deleteChunk`
• `getChapters`
• `getChunks`
• `updateChunks`
• `deleteChunks`
• `rehydrationLogic` endpoint (to rebuild the chapter structure)
*Naming Convention Dependency*
For all operations (insert / update / delete), we are relying on a strict doc naming convention.
Example filename:
 `Chapter-17_Section-III_Part-A_Subpart-1.docx`
We are assuming backend will always receive filenames in this format so we can reliably extract:
• Chapter
• Section
• Part
• Subpart
*Vector DB Attachment*
While storing the file into the Vector DB, we will also attach required metadata attributes (chapter/section/part/subpart) for accurate retrieval.
*Admin Dashboard Changes*
Since the backend endpoints + structure are changing, we will also need to make *some updates in the Admin Dashboard UI + integration* to align with the new endpoints and workflow.

Please review this approach and share feedback/suggestions
